title: Analysts brand Wisetech short report 'nonsense'
text:
Wisetech currently has a market capitalisation of over $10 billion as its revenue growth has been fuelled in part by a $642 million buying spree of 36 companies.

Sceptical investors however have been put off by the "roll up" strategy and the extent to which the company capitalises its spending on software development.

Mr Turner said some investors didn't understand the "beauty of the model" as Wisetech's acquisitions increase the capability of across platform, which drives usage and revenue from existing companies.

Wisetech is among the most expensive software companies in the world, and its elevated valuations has raised eyebrows among fund managers while attracting the attention of short sellers.

"People always talk about valuations, but when the consensus growth rates are multiplied out, the PE halves in two years if the share price stays the same and that's massive growth," Mr Turner said.

Meanwhile Evans & Partners, which also has a buy rating on the stock, published a seven point retort in an effort to pick apart the main claims of the JCap report.

'It said it disagreed with the point that Wisetech has overstated profits and revenues and double counted software costs to balance its books.

"They provide no real-world smoking gun evidence at all," Evans & Partners analyst Paul Mason said.

Mr Mason did however concede that he did not have a strong counter-argument with regard to the resignation of Christine Holman from the board after a relatively short tenure of 11 months.

"She looked pretty busy though with (I believe) six other major board positions on the go."

Ms Holman also serves as non-executive director of ASX listed companies of CSR and Blackmores.

Wisetech has been placed in a trading halt until Monday as it responds to the JCap report.

Shares in the company had slid over 10 per cent before the pause in trading was called.

Blue Ocean and Evans & Partners are among two of five analysts with buy ratings on the stock. Three analysts have a hold rating while two have sell ratings. The average price target among the ten analysts tracked by Bloomberg is $28.32, below the current $30 share price.
description: The analyst community have labelled a report that Wisetech is inflating its revenue as "nonsense" deriding short sellers for failing to understand the "beauty" of the $10 billion logistics company's acquisition led model.
